Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: I was just finishing up my lunch break at the workshop when my phone buzzed. It was my mom. Her voice trembled as she told me about Dad’s health scare that morning. She needed me—her only child—to listen, to reassure her, to be the steady presence she could lean on. I could hear the fear in her words, and I wanted nothing more than to rush home, sit beside her, and hold her hand. But as I tried to comfort her, my other phone rang. It was Mrs. Evans, the homeowner whose deck I’d promised to fix today. She sounded anxious, reminding me that her family gathering was tomorrow and the deck was unsafe. I could picture the splintered boards, the risk to her guests, and my responsibility as a carpenter to make it right. My heart pounded as I stood in the middle of the workshop, torn between being the child my parents needed and the professional my client depended on. Both roles pulled at me, their expectations heavy, and I felt the weight of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
